129.text:
Jupiter is the largest and most massive

It consists largely of hydrogen and
helium

Its largest storm, the Great Red Spot,

If you had a sufficiently large bathtub,

Saturn is also known for its extended,

168.text:
Uranus is the third largest planet
and one of the coldest.

172.text:
Of all the gas giants, it’s also
the smallest.

175.text:
The special thing about Uranus is that
its axis of rotation

178.text:
is tilted sideways in contrast to the

186.text:
Neptune is the last planet in the Solar
system and is similar to Uranus.

size and weight;

222.text: small Mercury, on the other hand,

228.text:
Jupiter is so massive that alone it

That’s a blessing for Earth, since

247.text:
But even Jupiter is a dwarf in

252.text:
Calling it massive does not do
justice to the Sun.

255.text:
It makes up 99.86% of the mass
in our Solar system.

260.text:
For the most part, it consists of
hydrogen and helium.

263.text:
Only less than 2% is made up of
heavy elements, like oxygen or iron.

269.text:
At its core, the Sun fuses 620 million
tons of hydrogen each second

274.text:

281.text:
But not only the eight planets
orbit our Sun.

284.text:
Trillions of asteroids and comets
also circle it.

288.text:
Most of them are concentrated into
two belts:

291.text:
the asteroid belt between Mars and
Jupiter

295.text:
and the Kuiper belt at the edge of the
Solar system.

298.text:
These belts are home to countless
objects, some as large as a dust particle,

302.text: others the size of dwarf planets.

306.text:
The most well-known object in the
asteroid belt is Ceres;

309.text:
the most well-known objects in the Kuiper
belt are Pluto, Makemake and Haumea.

316.text: Usually we describe the asteroid belt as

318.text:
a dense collection of bodies that
constantly collide.

322.text:
But in fact, the asteroids are
distributed across an area that is

326.text:
so indescribably large that it’s even
difficult to see two asteroids at once.

332.text: Despite the billions of objects in them,

334.text:
the asteroid belts are fairly empty
places.

337.text:
And nonetheless, there are collisions
over and over again.

341.text:
The mass of both belts is also
unimpressive:

344.text:
the asteroid belt has a little less than
4% of our Moon’s mass, and

349.text:
the Kuiper belt is only between one 25th
and one 10th of Earth’s mass.

357.text:
One day, the Solar system will cease to
exist.

360.text:

maybe Earth too will be destroyed.

366.text:
In 500 million years it will become hotter
and hotter until at some point

375.text:
Then the Sun will grow and grow and
either swallow Earth

378.text: or at least turn it into a sea of lava.

384.text:
When it has burnt up all its fuel and
lost most of its mass,

387.text:
it will shrink to a white dwarf and burn
gently for a few billion more years

396.text:
Then, at the latest, life in the Solar
system will no longer be possible.

401.text: The Milky Way will not even notice it.

404.text:
A small part of it in one of its arms
will become just a tiny bit darker.

408.text:
And mankind will cease to exist
or leave the Solar system
